entry.title: Visualizing Login Attempts
entry.content:
In my previous post, I created a simple script to figure out which countries had people trying to login to my server. Iâ€™d have to manually ssh in to my server, copy + paste this script, and then run it to see what I wanted to see. I decided I wanted to be able to check up on this from a web browser, so I went ahead and made that happen.

First thingâ€™s first, I installed Apache and made sure I could hit my server.

Then I experimented with cron jobs, because I hadnâ€™t ever set one up before. There were a couple gotchas:

  • You wonâ€™t see the output unless you route it somewhere else. I had date set to run every minute, but nothing happened until I redirected output to a log file.
  • You need to give a path to the script if youâ€™re running it. For some reason I thought I could just say firstCron.sh instead of ~/firstCron.sh, so this one was a very simple mistake.
* * * * * date >> ~/simple.log
* * * * * ~/firstCron.sh

Some useful commands are:

  • crontab -l to list your crontab file
  • crontab -e to edit your crontab file
  • Prepending sudo to the above commands to have root run your cron jobs

I set up a cron job to run every hour that gets the IPs, looks their geography up, sorts the output, counts the unique countries, writes this out to a file, and puts that file on the server at /logins (location subject to change). The result looks like this:

Nothing crazy, but it is far more convenient that it was before to see who is trying to log in.

entry.title: Setting up a Jekyll Blog with Github Pages

entry.content:
